results.title: Shaft in Africa
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Shaft Productions, Roger Lewis and John Guillermin
results.brief_description: Super-slick detective John Shaft (Richard Roundtree) is back in this violent and action-packed follow up to “Shaft” (1971) and “Shaft’s Big Score” (1972). This time, Shaft is persuaded by African diplomats at the United Nations to hunt down and expose the operator of a sinister slave-trading racket. After receiving lessons in African customs from the diplomat’s beautiful daughter, Aleme (Vonetta McGee), Shaft goes to Africa and, posing as a native, allows himself to be captured. Things appear to be going smoothly until a traitor in the organisation reveals Shaft’s true identity. Forced to fend off attacks on his life using only traditional fighting methods, Shaft is caught in a race against time to bring the ruthless, murderous traders to justice. ‘Shaft in Africa’ is a bold, fast-paced film featuring memorable dialogue, saucy images, and a funky soundtrack. Richard Roundtree won an MTV Movie Award for lifetime achievement in 1994 for his roles in the Shaft films.

results.title: Shaft
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Joel Freeman and Gordon Parks
results.brief_description: This otherwise straight forward detective film’s reputation was mainly attributed to its funky Academy Award winning title song by Isaac Hayes and for it’s mainly black cast and lead (Richard Roundtree) - a rare event in 1971 for a major studio picture. Hollywood, always slow to catch on, cashed in on the growing ‘blaxploitation’ market whose B-Grade genre films tapped into the largely ignored black cinema going audience. Although some cross over hits occurred, films like ‘Shaft’ (which also spawned an unsuccessful television series) generally played it safe, leaving the more radical ventures into black cinema for the likes of maverick directors such as Melvin Van Peebles, whose film ‘Sweet Backs Baadassss Song’ was released the same year as ‘Shaft’. Detective John Shaft (Roundtree) takes on the Mafia when he is enlisted by a black crime boss to help get back his kidnapped daughter. Shaft calls in on his underground connections to help him solve the case, all the while trying to dodge the bumbling New York police department. Cast also includes Moses Gunn, Christopher St. John and Charles Cioffi. (Awards: 1972 Academy Award Best Music, Song- Isaac Hayes)

results.title: Shadows on the snow = Skuggor over snon
results.creator_credit: Kort Film, Svensk Filmindustri and Arne Sucksdorff
results.brief_description: In the winter forest, a bear frightens a small boy whose father then sets out with his dog to track the huge animal. The chase lasts into the darkness, where even this experienced hunter retreats in panic, for as Sucksdorff characteristically says he realises “that senses stronger than his are masters of the night”. Full of the beauty and the terror of the struggle to live, it also displays the distinctive Scandinavian approach to nature in which, “wood, wind and water are still alive”.

results.title: Shadows of the peacock = Echoes of paradise
results.creator_credit: Laughing Kookaburra Productions, Jane Scott and Phil Noyce
results.brief_description: A married woman, and mother of three youngsters, is devastated by the infidelities of her philandering husband, which coincides with the death of her beloved father. With the view to reassess her life, she absconds to Thailand where she falls for a beautiful Balinese dancer. Despite her enjoyment of sexual fulfilment, freedom to explore her desire, and space for reflection away from her conventional suburban life, Maria is conflicted about her maternal duties and obligations. This interesting, early work by Phillip Noyce, intelligently probes the themes of female independence, motherhood and female sexuality within the context of ‘the other’ in this case being Maria’s lover. Maria questions her attraction in light of his exoticism and culture, which contrasts sharply to her rigid upbringing. Stars a young Claudia Karvan as Maria’s daughter. Also known as “Echoes of paradise”.

results.title: Shadows of our forgotten ancestors = Wild Horses of Fire
results.brief_description: Shadows of our forgotten ancestors was the film with which the Armenian Sergo Paradjanov first came to fame in the West. The story, drawn from Carpathian folklore, and set amongst the Huzul people, is a fairly conventional tale of blighted love, but what really distinguishes the film is its flamboyant visual style, its florid romanticism and its delirious pantheism - none of which endeared it to the Soviet authorities. The story begins with a blodd feud between two village clans, the wealthy Gutenyuks and the poor Pallicuks, and ends with a fight to death between two men. The film is a jungian parable: the ‘pure’ shepherd Ivan (Ivan Mikolaichuk) quest for reunion with is own ‘anima’, as represented by true love Marichka (Larissa Kadochnikova). Adpated from novel by Mikhail Kotzubinsky. In Ukrainian with English sub-titles. See also: Paradjanov’s “Caucasus Trilogy”: The Colour of Pomegranates & The Legend of the Suram Fortress. Ashik Kerib.

results.title: Shadows and fog
results.brief_description: The circus comes to town and fog covers a small European town as the locals, gripped by fear, band together to form vigilante groups to rid themselves of a strangler at large. Woody Allen plays a timid and fearful man who has been roped into one of the vigilante groups to find that he spends his time haplessly pitted against each faction within the vigilantes. A comedy of errors, ‘Shadows and Fog’ draws on its A-grade hollywood cast to create almost a disintegration of film epitomised by the bumbling incompetencies of Allen’s character who wanders alongide the main action like a narrator. The more the film follows Allen’s character the further we digress into a world of iconic noir references whilst quietly accompanied by some of Allen’s best gags. Cast includes Mia Farrow, John Malkovich, Donald Pleasence, Lily Tomlin, John Cusack, Jodie Foster, Kathy Bates, Fred Gwynne, Madonna and Woody Allen.

results.title: Shadows
results.creator_credit: Cassavetes, McEndree, Cassel Productions, Maurice McEndree and John Cassavetes
results.brief_description: ‘Shadows’ was a vanguard work of the independent American cinema, a bittersweet comedy centred on three African-American outsiders - Lelia and his two jazz-musicians brothers living in Greenwich Village - two of whom pass for white and all are part of the late fifties ‘lost generation’. We follow Lelia through three brief romantic involvements. Although the film was recognised at the time for its treatment of race, Cassavetes saw this as incidental to the wider question of identity. His special commitment to expression through performance and a concomitant openness of form give his films a rough, uninflected, anecdotal quality (a form of ‘fictional cinema verite’). ‘Shadows’, like other Cassavetes’ films was fully scripted despite the reference in the end title to the film as ‘an improvisation’. Cast includes Lelia Goldoni, Ben Carruthers, Hugh Hurd.

results.title: Shadows
results.brief_description: This film is a personal journey, a form of diary that ventures into the territory of the unconscious. It is based upon the exploration of the body’s movements whilst asleep. “Shadows” was shot over two consecutive nights during real sleep. With Adam Buscomb and D.M. Parrish. No commentary - music performed by Dalmonico Babari and Rommy Reinhard.
